Define complete AST node hierarchy with base interfaces and all node types (Expression, Statement, Declaration, Type nodes). Include visitor pattern support for future compiler phases and ensure all nodes carry source position information.

Implement parser core infrastructure including parser state, token consumption utilities, operator precedence table, and synchronization helpers. This provides the foundation for all parsing operations.

Implement expression parsing with full operator precedence using Pratt parsing or precedence climbing algorithm. Cover all expression types including literals, identifiers, unary/binary operators, function calls, member access, and grouping expressions.

Design data structures and types for syntax error handling, including enums for error severity, recovery modes (e.g., Panic, None), and a robust `SyntaxError` struct that captures token, expected, actual, and span information.

Implement algorithms to calculate synchronization points (Follow Sets) for various grammar productions. This involves analyzing the grammar rules to determine valid tokens that can follow a non-terminal.
Implement the core Panic Mode recovery routine. This function consumes tokens from the lexer until a token in the current Follow Set is found or EOF is reached.

Test Fixtures and Golden Master Data
Lexer Unit Tests

Integrate recovery triggers into the Parser's main loop. Modify the parsing functions to catch mismatches, report errors via the `ErrorReporter`, and invoke the `synchronize` function instead of immediately bailing out.
Implement safeguards to prevent infinite loops during recovery, such as limiting the number of consumed tokens or detecting if the parser is stuck at the same token without progress.
Implement the adapter/bridge that formats `SyntaxError` objects into human-readable messages and integrates with the existing Diagnostics/Logging system.

Implement comprehensive error detection, recovery, and reporting for the parser. Define error types, implement error detection for all syntax violations, create helpful error messages with context, and ensure parsing can continue after errors to report multiple issues.

Implement while loop and for loop parsing. For loops support C-style syntax (init; condition; increment). Both loops support block or single-statement bodies. Include tests for various loop forms and edge cases.

Implement return, break, and continue statement parsing with context validation. Track parsing context (inside loop, inside function) to validate jump statements are used correctly. Return can have optional value expression. Include tests for valid and invalid contexts.

Implement the Error Emission API and Buffering Logic. Create a ParseResult wrapper or error buffer that allows the parser to accumulate errors without stopping immediately. Implement helper methods like expect_token() that detect violations and emit errors.

Implement the Error Recovery Engine (Synchronization Strategy). Define 'synchronization sets' (e.g., stop at semicolons, braces, keywords). Implement the algorithm to discard tokens until a valid synchronization point is found, allowing the parser to resume.

Integrate Error Handling and Recovery into Parser State Machine. Refactor existing parser production rules (expressions, statements, declarations) to use the expect() and emit_error() helpers, and call synchronize() upon failure to continue parsing subsequent top-level nodes.

Implement core control flow foundation types, traits, and interfaces. Define BlockID type for unique block identification, Terminator trait as base for all control-flow-ending instructions, ControlFlowInstruction trait for instructions affecting control flow, and iterator types for successor/predecessor traversal. Establish the type contracts that all other control flow structures will depend on.

Implement BasicBlock structure as the fundamental IR unit. Each BasicBlock contains a sequence of instructions, a single terminator instruction at the end, and tracks predecessor blocks. Include validation ensuring exactly one terminator exists (except possibly for entry blocks under construction). Support adding instructions, setting terminator, and computing successors from the terminator.

Implement branch and return terminator instructions. Create UnconditionalBranch (single target), ConditionalBranch (condition value + two targets), and Return (optional return value). Each must implement the Terminator trait, validate target blocks exist, and ensure condition values are of boolean/comparable type. Provide constructors that integrate with AST lowering.

Implement Switch instruction for multi-way branching. Create SwitchInstruction structure with a switch value, vector of (case_value, target_block) pairs, and optional default target block. Validate that all case values are unique and of the same type as the switch value. Support construction from AST switch/case statements.

Implement Phi node structure for Static Single Assignment (SSA) form. PhiNode represents a merge of values from multiple predecessor blocks at control flow join points. Store the phi result type and a list of (incoming_block, incoming_value) pairs. Validate that all incoming values have the same type matching the phi type. Ensure phi nodes are only placed at the beginning of blocks.

Implement Control Flow Graph (CFG) container structure. CFG owns and manages a collection of BasicBlocks, tracks the entry block, and provides methods for adding, removing, and retrieving blocks. Maintain consistency between blocks (ensure predecessor/successor lists are accurate). Provide lookup by BlockId and iteration over blocks in various orders (insertion order, reverse post-order).
